content.text:
A 53-year-old man suffers a cardiac arrest and his wife calls paramedics, who arrive a few minutes later and begin resuscitative measures. A regular heart rate is established after about 40 minutes of resuscitative efforts as he is being transported to the hospital. A thrombolytic agent is administered on admission. Which of the following cellular changes is most likely to now be occurring within his myocardium? <image 1> 

A. Apoptosis
B. Free radical injury
C. Heterophagocytosis
D. Squamous metaplasia

The image provided shows a histological section of tissue, which appears to be cardiac muscle based on the striated appearance of the cells. Given the context of a cardiac arrest and subsequent resuscitation, the most likely cellular change occurring within the myocardium would be:

B. Free radical injury

During cardiac arrest, there is a significant reduction in blood flow to the heart, leading to ischemia (lack of oxygen). When blood flow is restored during resuscitation, reactive oxygen species (ROS) or free radicals are produced, which can cause damage to the myocardial cells. This process is known as reperfusion injury and is characterized by free radical production.

Apoptosis (programmed cell death) might also occur but is less immediate compared to free radical injury. Heterophagocytosis (the engulfing of foreign material by cells) and squamous metaplasia (a type of cell transformation) are not typically associated with the immediate aftermath of cardiac arrest and resuscitation.
Now, output the final answer and nothing else:
